title: How to Make Iranian Bread

steps.headline: Mix together the yeast and the lukewarm water, then let stand for 5 minutes.
Combine the salt and flour, then add to the yeast and water mixture, mixing everything together thoroughly.
Knead the dough until it's very smooth.
steps.description: You can choose to mix it in a standing mixer (which will take about 6-7 minutes), or to knead the dough by hand on a floured surface.

steps.headline: Coat the inside of a bowl with about 1 tsp of oil.
steps.description: Place your dough in the bowl, cover the bowl with plastic wrap, and let stand for about an hour, or until the dough has doubled in size.

steps.headline: Shape the dough.
steps.description: Divide the dough into two halves, then shape each half into an oval, punching it down to flatten it.

steps.headline: Let the dough rest again.
steps.description: Place the two ovals on an oiled baking sheet. Cover a sheet of plastic wrap in oil, cover the ovals with the plastic wrap, and let it rise for 1 hour, or until they have doubled in size again.

steps.headline: Make the roomal.
steps.description: While you're waiting for your dough to rise, combine flour, oil, sugar, and water in a medium saucepan and cook over medium heat, whisking it until it has thickened (approximately 2 minutes). After it has thickened, remove it from heat and let it cool.

steps.headline: Pre-heat the oven.
steps.description: While waiting for the dough to rise, pre-heat the oven to 450F.

steps.headline: Create ridges in the dough.
steps.description: Use your fingers to make 5 deep ridges running lengthwise through your dough.

steps.headline: Cover with roomal.
steps.description: Divide the roomal in half and cover each half of dough with the roomal. If you would like to use the sesame and/or nigella seeds, sprinkle them on top of the dough as well.

steps.headline: Place the dough on a baking sheet and bake for 15-18 minutes, or until golden brown.

text: Mix together the yeast and the lukewarm water, then let stand for 5 minutes.  Combine the salt and flour, then add to the yeast and water mixture, mixing everything together thoroughly.  Knead the dough until it's very smooth. You can choose to mix it in a standing mixer (which will take about 6-7 minutes), or to knead the dough by hand on a floured surface. Coat the inside of a bowl with about 1 tsp of oil. Place your dough in the bowl, cover the bowl with plastic wrap, and let stand for about an hour, or until the dough has doubled in size. Shape the dough. Divide the dough into two halves, then shape each half into an oval, punching it down to flatten it. Let the dough rest again. Place the two ovals on an oiled baking sheet. Cover a sheet of plastic wrap in oil, cover the ovals with the plastic wrap, and let it rise for 1 hour, or until they have doubled in size again. Make the roomal. While you're waiting for your dough to rise, combine flour, oil, sugar, and water in a medium saucepan and cook over medium heat, whisking it until it has thickened (approximately 2 minutes). After it has thickened, remove it from heat and let it cool. Pre-heat the oven. While waiting for the dough to rise, pre-heat the oven to 450F. Create ridges in the dough. Use your fingers to make 5 deep ridges running lengthwise through your dough. Cover with roomal. Divide the roomal in half and cover each half of dough with the roomal. If you would like to use the sesame and/or nigella seeds, sprinkle them on top of the dough as well. Place the dough on a baking sheet and bake for 15-18 minutes, or until golden brown.
